question.title: Practical use cases for a property and a method in enum to have the same name in Java
question.body:
I was going through this tutorial and found the following code:

    // ... enum constants ...
    private final double mass;   // in kilograms
    private final double radius; // in meters
    // ... enum constructor ...
    private double mass() { return mass; }
    private double radius() { return radius; }

Why does it define the mass and radius methods? Both variables and methods are private, so what purpose does it serve?

More generally, in what cases it is helpful to define a method with the same name and same access modifier as a variable?

Edit: I am aware of getters and setters. Firstly, the methods are NOT named getMass() and getRadius() as usual for getters, rather they have the exact same name as the properties. Secondly, I specifically mentioned that I am confused because both the properties and the methods are private. I don't see how this is a duplicate of this one.

answers.body: The mass() and radius() methods in the Oracle tutorial are private, unused, and unnecessary. They were likely included just to show that enums can have methods, but they don't serve any purpose in the code. In real-world code, they should be removed or renamed and used properly.

Why no get?

The community, and this notably includes the JDK itself, is confused about how to write a getter. The majority write a get prefix but there is a signficant minority that does not.

This is a bad idea; get is the name of the thing as per the vast, vast majority of java programmers (they are called 'getters' after all!), and get has pragmatic advantages: They clearly identify "this method retrieves a property, it has no side effects other than potentially some caching shenanigans, and represents the state as it is now". It also means you can type get and hit auto-complete in your editor and see them all.

However, the record feature auto-generates getter-like constructs for you and does not include the get prefix. Apparently a mistake, but OpenJDK does not think so and continues to defend the choice. Not that it matters at this point; with the feature released out of preview the cost of changing it now is far higher than the damage done by failing to add those get prefixes. Point is: With records now part of standard java, the confusion about whether getters start with get or not is complete.

So, it's just a choice. Some folks like writing their getters with get in front.

What use is this?

It's varied:

  1. You can write method handles, you cannot write field handles. If I want to write the notion "Given an instance of X, turn it into the value of this property of X", I can simply write X::getX, for example in someListOfX.map().stream(X::getX)..... There is no such syntax for fields. Thus, having the method there means you can write this. Even if no such code is in there right now, 'YAGNI' is just a rule of thumb; if you know it is highly likely that you'll need it, or it feels right for the API you are designing, you should add such things. Or at least, one could plausibly think one should.

  2. If many places do the job of 'access property foo of myself', and you are thinking that perhaps in the future you want to e.g. add a logging line, or some caching stuff, to that job, then, for the same reason you don't want to repeat "someTrickyConstantValue" 85 times throughout a single source file (you'd want to do private static final String SOME_DESCRIPTOR = "someTrickyConstantValue"; and use that constant instead), you'd want all such accesses to go through a single method, so that if later you want to add logging, caching, normalizing, or whatever, you can do that in one place.

  3. It somewhat indemnifies you to later change. If later on one notices that the field can actually go away and be live calculated, then you'd have to change all code if all code uses a field access. Now, you don't. For example, imagine we go from this:

enum Rank {
  SPADES("black"), HEARTS("red"), CLUBS("black"), DIAMONDS("red");

  ... infra for having a field named 'color'.

  private String color() { return color; }
}

to:

enum Rank {
  SPADES, HEARTS, CLUBS, DIAMONDS;

  private String color() {
    return switch (this) {
      case SPADES, CLUBS -> "black";
      case HEARTS, DIAMONDS -> "red";
    };
  }
}

Then that can be done without having to change any calling code at all... if you had that method there.

These are all somewhat esoteric. They don't have to be fantastic reasons. Just.. good enough to plausibly explain why someone might want to do this.

question_comments.body: By the way, you may want to go through the more modern tutorials. Here's the enum page: dev.java/learn/classes-objects/enums

"in what cases it is helpful to define a method with the same name and same access modifier as a variable?" --> one use case I can think of: allow the use of method references (in place of the corresponding lambda expression -- Planet::mass ↔ p -> p.mass ) -- not the case in mentioned tutorial, but I have no idea why the author did so

The duplicate added to the dup list is more appropriate and should answer your question, at least somewhat. Many of the reasons mostly only apply if you have a corresponding setter, but some apply to only having a getter. However, the tutorial having those private getters still makes no sense because they are never used. As for their names, prefixing with "get" is a widespread convention but it's not a hard and fast rule. You can see examples even in the standard library where a method that's fundamentally a getter is not prefixed with "get".

It would be more than interesting that those who voted to close the question, before doing so... read, the question is whether it makes sense to have private setters* and getters, and it is not duplicate of the question, to which they refer, Hello Asif, with respect to the question, in general we could say that it is nonsense, although we should think well in the case of an internal class, that although these methods are marked as “private”, you can access them, so that an internal object, could modify the state of the external, and no other object could do it.

Honestly, in that tutorial having those two private methods does not make sense to me. They're not even used elsewhere in the class (the fields are accessed directly). And they can't be used outside the class because they're private.

79619496.body: “Map's keySet() is absolutely not a getter”—perfect, so we agree on that. Likewise, name() on an enum constant is absolutely not a getter. And yes, there are cases where people may have long discussions whether one or the other pattern is more suitable, but that’s not the point. The point is, both patterns are almost as old as Java and both are well established. Don’t call one a mistake just because you find it annoying.
Map's keySet() is absolutely not a getter, that's exactly the point.

get as a prefix has little to do with beans. It came from there originally. Your argument is similar to "switch came from C, C99 changed how it works, so java should follow suit". How java gained its switch statement is a fun historical story but mostly irrelevant. And how 'get' got to be 'get' is similarly irrelevant. Hence, 'record types are not beans' is not relevant. The community used get a lot. records not using them is annoying and a mistake. For every name() and ordinal() I can give you a getYear(). Neither camp had 100%. Examples are thus irrelevant too.

The pattern of having getters and potentially setters belongs to the Java Beans convention but record types are not Beans. The pattern of having methods without a get prefix for immutable artifacts is as old as Java, see Integer’s intValue() method or, as we’re talking about an enum type in this Q&A, see its name() and ordinal() methods. Likewise, annotations have accessor methods without a get prefix and a Map has keySet(), entrySet() and values(), again, no get prefix…
